author: Caroline Mcguire for MailOnline
title: Brits reveal predictions for future of air travel and it includes WiFi on ALL planes
text:

Today is October 21, 2015, the day that Marty McFly and Doc Brown travelled to in the Eighties film Back To The Future II, and several of the movie's predictions, including 3D films and Video-call communication, came true.
But now Brits are trying their own hand at soothsaying, by guessing what air travel will look like in the future.
In a recent survey, seasoned travellers shared their hopes for the future of flying, including improved aeroplane food, vending machines on board and segregated child seating.
A new survey has asked Brits what they want from air travel in the future. Many revealed they wanted high street food brands sold on board (Picture posed by models)
The study, by Monarch Airlines, asked 2,000 UK adults what advances in air travel they wanted over the next five to ten years.
The most popular request by far was internet connections, with 77 per cent of people questioned admitting they would like WiFi on every plane.
Almost half of those questioned also predicted that personalised digital seat panels will be commonplace over the next few years.

They think the chairs will come complete with individual welcome messages, 3D entertainment and duty-free advertising on board aircraft, as advertisers look to maximise on the potential of a captive audience.
Those polled also had expectations on changes for holidaymakers traveling with children, with 30 per cent of people surveyed hoping for the introduction of segregated child seating areas on planes, with one per cent even wishing for on-board nannies.
Despite great strides taking place in aeroplane food over recent years, the issue was still a point of contention among travellers, with many wishing to see more change.
The majority of respondents said they wanted WiFi available on all flights (Picture posed by model)
Twenty per cent of those asked are hoping to see UK high-street food brands served on-board, with 23 per cent envisaging 'serve-yourself' style vending machines in the galleys.
Four percent even foresaw software that would allow for fresh groceries to be delivered to their home for when you got back from holiday.
In-flight pampering is also tipped to be a big thing in the 2020's - nine per cent of those surveyed would like to see separate relaxation areas on-board, with four per cent requesting the services of beauty and relaxation therapists too.
